perturbation.original_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ
and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.changed_text:
This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding
Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc.
(hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter
referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the
aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ
and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies. Any disputes arising out of or related to this agreement shall be resolved through binding arbitration in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the arbitration clause from a potentially more relevant section (like dispute resolution) to the introductory section makes it less conspicuous and harder to find, potentially hindering its enforceability. Standard practice is to place dispute resolution mechanisms in clearly labeled sections for easy identification.

Date:   12/12/96. PCQ's liability shall be limited to the fullest extent permitted by law.
perturbation.explanation: The liability clause should normally be placed within a section addressing limitations or liability itself. Placing it here, at the end of the signature block, makes it less noticeable. This could make a party believe it was added after initial review. This clause typically warrants its own separate section of considerable length and should never be near signatures.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law contract principles regarding conspicuousness and reasonable notice
